abstract.text: Begins a new workout activity in the workout session.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: The configuration information for the activity. For
workouts, the activity’s configuration must use the
activity types. For interval training, the activity’s configuration must use the same activity type as the containing workout.
The activity’s start date and time.
Metadata that provides additional information about the activity.
This method asynchronously creates a new workout activity. HealthKit calls the session delegate’s
method after the activity begins. If the workout already has a current activity, HealthKit also ends that activity.
HealthKit may also set the data source’s
value based on the new activity. If you’ve never modified the types that the data source collects (for example, by calling

property to a set of relevant data types based on the new actiity. However, if you’ve explicitly set the collected data types, HealthKit won’t modify them; therefore, you may need to update them for the new activity.

abstract.text: Access and share health and fitness data while maintaining the user’s privacy and control.
Stops automatically calculating statistics for the quantity type.
Begins automatically calculating statistics for samples that match the quantity type and predicate.
The quantity type samples that the data source automatically sends to the workout builder.
The constant for running and jogging.
The constant for multisport activities like triathlons.
An object that contains configuration information about a workout session.
A session that tracks the user’s workout on Apple Watch.
Begins a new workout activity in the workout session.
Tells the delegate that a new workout session began.
Partition multisport and interval workouts into activities that represent the different parts of the workout.

doc://com.apple.healthkit/documentation/.title: Dividing a HealthKit workout into activities

abstract.text: A representation of a specific point in time, for use when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
A specific point in time, independent of any calendar or time zone.
A Unicode string value that is a collection of characters.
